name: Oceanic Animal Sizes

content.markdown:
## {data[0].sample_count} Oceanic Sizes: Small Fry to Whales

Explore the diversity of oceanic adjacent animals and shapes, with a focus on their length (in cm). Data from [MOBS_OPEN](https://github.com/crmcclain/MOBS_OPEN).

### Phylum Drilldown

Use the two charts on the left to drill down. The show the largest families and genera in the filter set. Click on the family to narrow down the genera list, click on the genera list to explore. 
You can use the top global filter bar to restrict directly to a subset if you have a target in mind.

3.content:
where length_cm is not null
select
    # genus.name,
    class,
    avg(length_cm) as avg_length_cm,
    count(genus.name) as total_genera,
order by
    avg_length_cm desc
limit 25
3.name: Length By Class

6.content:
where length_cm is not null
select

    column00,
    family,
    length_cm as sample_length_cm,
    avg(length_cm) by genus.name as avg_genus_size
order by
    avg_genus_size desc,
    family asc,
    sample_length_cm asc;
6.name: Distribution of Sizes

7.content:
select  
    scientificName,  
    phylum,
    genus.name,
    class,  
    genus.image,
    avg(length_cm) as avg_length_cm,  
    sample_count,
    --rank scientificName by avg_length_cm asc as rank_asc,  
    --rank scientificName by avg_length_cm desc as rank_desc  ,
    -- rank genus.name by avg(length_cm) by genus.name desc as genus_filter
having 
    genus_filter = 1
order by  
    rank_desc asc  
limit 20;
7.name: Largest and Smallest Species

9.content:
select
    round(avg(length_cm),4) as avg_length_cm,
    count(scientificName) as species_count,
    count(phylum) as phylum_count,
    count(class) as class_count,
    count(family) as family_count,
    # count(column00) as total_samples,
order by
    avg_length_cm desc
limit 15;
9.name: Summary Statistics

14.content:
SELECT
    genus.image,
    --genus.name,
    -- avg(length_cm) by genus.name as avg_length
order by 
    avg_length desc
    limit 1;
14.name: Biggest Boi

content.markdown:
## {data[0].genus_name || N/A} ({data[0].family || N/A})

This section shows more details for the largest genus ({data[0].genus_name || N/A}) in your current filter set. {data[0].genus_name || N/A} contains **{data[0].species_count || 0}** species listed at bottom.
content.query:
select
    genus.name,
    family,
    count(scientificName) as species_count,
    --avg(length_cm) as avg_length
order by avg_length desc
    limit 1;

18.content:
where length_cm is not null and length_cm > 0  
select  
     log_length_bin,  
    sample_count  
order by  
    log_length_bin asc  
limit 100;
18.name: Size Groupings

19.content:
where length_cm is not null
select
    genus.name,
    # class,
    avg(length_cm) as avg_length_cm,
    count(scientificName) as total_species,
order by
    avg_length_cm desc
limit 25
19.name: Avg Length By Genus

content.query:
SELECT
    genus.description,
    --genus.name,
    -- avg(length_cm) as avg_length
order by 
    avg_length desc
    limit 1;

description: This dashboard provides an in-depth exploration of aquatic animal sizing samples, focusing primarily on length measurements across a wide range of species from small fish to whales. The visualizations highlight differences by taxonomic class and genus, revealing distribution patterns, size extremes, and relationships between length and height. Use interactive charts to drill down into specific classes and genera, and explore the tables for detailed species insights.
